docs.lead_paragraph: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York. Senate 1. Tax-Exempt Groups: Vote on a bill to require a growing number of tax-exempt groups that raise and spend unlimited amounts on political advocacy to disclose their donors and spending. Approved 92 to 6, June 29. 2. Genetics: Vote on a Republican amendment to a spending bill for the Departments of Labor, Education and Health and Human Services that would prevent insurance companies from basing coverage or premiums on genetic information but would not prohibit employers from using genetic information in hiring and workplace promotion or salaries. Approved 54 to 44, June 29.

docs.lead_paragraph: WILL the caring, dedicated insurance salesman -- mythologized for decades in television commercials, less frequently spotted in real life -- survive and thrive in a dot-com world? The insurance industry by nature is conservative and tradition-bound, preferring to stick with the tried and true and leave the risks and rewards of innovation to others. In recent years, it has managed to hold out against pressure to re-engineer around the demands of an Internet-driven economy. Meanwhile, other financial service industries like the brokerage business have been turned nearly upside down and inside out as customers flocked online.

headline.main: Insurance Industry Confronts an Internet Future

docs.abstract: Insurance industry, conservative and tradition-bound, belatedly accepts Internet as agency owners and sales personnel digitalize in order to reduce costs and paperwork and reap other benefits of automation; Comprehensive Planning-Goodman, agency in Hicksville, Long Island, unveils new e-commerce site; photo (M)
docs.snippet: WILL the caring, dedicated insurance salesman -- mythologized for decades in television commercials, less frequently spotted in real life -- survive and thrive in a dot-com world?    The insurance industry by nature is conservative and...

docs.lead_paragraph: JOSEPH HADDAD, a pediatric ear, nose and throat doctor in Manhattan, said he realized how dropping out of managed care was paying off for him as he sat watching his son's preschool graduation. Dr. Haddad's workload has shrunk markedly -- 20 percent fewer surgical cases, a similar decline in office visits -- since he stopped abiding by the insurers' fee scales last year. Now he is home for dinner most nights and can attend his older son's activities. ''You realize how important that is when your kid keeps waving at you the whole time,'' he said, recalling the graduation ceremony. Ditching managed care, he said, ''was really a quality-of-life issue.''
docs.abstract: Jennifer Steinhauer Money & Medicine column notes a number of doctors around the country have decided to stop settling for frequently inadequate reimbursement offered by managed care plans and have begun accepting patients who pay cash or have access to indemnity insurance; notes doctors lose many patients, and may make still less money, but they enjoy improved quality of life; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR the stirring announcement that scientists have more or less succeeded in mapping the human genome, the private sector deserves a lot of the credit. The energy and innovation of one company, the Celera Genomics Group, a unit of the PE Corporation, transformed a plodding effort run by a public consortium into a feverish race. The job got done faster than expected, and lives may be saved. But another important conclusion must be drawn from this milestone, one that is crucial to business people lately inured to such heresy. It is that Uncle Sam is not the consummate bumbler he's made out to be.

headline.main: The Invisible Hand of Uncle Sam

docs.abstract: Daniel Akst On the Contrary column contends mapping of human genome, project in which Celera Genomics Group competed with government-backed consortium, disproves notion that government can't do anything; contends the trick is to be sensible, not dogmatic, about which things government can do and which it should leave to business; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a $21.4 billion state budget into law today after using her line-item veto to carve $50 million in spending proposed by the Legislature. The budget, buoyed by windfall tax revenues generated by New Jersey's surging economy, represents a 10 percent increase over last year's spending, and includes a $45 million tax cut for 240,000 low-income families, and FamilyCare, the Governor's plan to use part of the tobacco settlement to help provide health insurance for 125,000 New Jerseyans.

headline.main: Whitman Trims $21.4 Billion Budget Before Signing It

docs.abstract: New Jersey Governor Christine Todd Whitman signs $21.4 billion state budget into law after using line-item veto to trim $50 million in spending proposed by Legislature; budget represents 10 percent increase over last year's spending and includes $45 million tax cut for 240,000 low-income families, and FamilyCare, Governor's plan to use portion of tobacco settlement to help provide health insurance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was nearing 10 o'clock at night, but in the sweltering lecture hall that served as the stage for this political rally, the Green Party's nominee for president of the United States was still going strong. He sharply criticized an ''apartheid economy'' that was benefiting only the rich, and he bemoaned the state of affairs in a country with ''far more problems than it deserves and far more solutions than it applies.'' And he scoffed at the notion that he might be a spoiler, drawing enough votes away from Al Gore to tip the election to George W. Bush.
docs.abstract: Ralph Nader is running aggressively as Green Party candidate for president this year, in contrast to his low-cost symbolic race in 1996; Nader draws attention from media and left-learning voters who see him as more liberal than Al Gore; he is drawing five to ten percent in polls, and sees West Coast as fertile ground for railing against 'Republicrats'; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Elated with a big victory in the House, doctors opened a campaign today to persuade the Senate to give them an exemption from antitrust laws so they could bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues. But the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, Republican of Mississippi, said he would stand in their way.

headline.main: Doctor's Antitrust Hopes Face a Roadblock From Lott

docs.abstract: Senate Republican leader Trent Lott will fight House-passed bill to exempt doctors from major provisions of antitrust laws; photo; Republican Repr Tom Campbell and AMA allies say House's lopsided 276-136 vote will give them momentum in Senate, although Lott's opposition reduces chance of passage this year; also opposed are other medical practitioners and antitrust officials at FTC and Justice Department, who see doctors raising fees (M)
docs.snippet: Elated with a big victory in the House, doctors opened a campaign today to persuade the Senate to give them an exemption from antitrust laws so they could bargain collectively with insurance companies over fees and other issues.    But the Senate...

docs.lead_paragraph: THE REFORM PARTY PEROT WILL NOT RUN -- Ross Perot, a two-time presidential candidate, decided yesterday against putting his name on the Reform Party's primary ballot, removing a big potential roadblock for Patrick J. Buchanan's candidacy. A Perot spokesman, Russell Verney, said Mr. Perot decided against running because he had no intention of actually competing for the White House against Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the Republican contender, and Vice President Al Gore, his Democratic rival. A daylong series of meetings at Mr. Perot's office in Dallas included ''intense pressure'' to put his name on the ballot in an effort to stop Mr. Buchanan, Mr. Verney said. But Mr. Perot felt it would be unethical to seek the nomination but not really run, he said. Another difficulty was that Mr. Perot would have appeared on only about half the states' ballots in November. His decision to forgo a place on the primary ballot leaves two candidates who say they have enough support to win spots there: Mr. Buchanan, a former Republican, and the Natural Law Party candidate, John Hagelin. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: After citing ''serious concerns'' about flaws in an initiative by New York City to move one million poor residents on Medicaid into managed care health plans, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall approved a two-year extension of the program yesterday, along with a list of recommendations on how to improve the effort. Mr. McCall spent several months reviewing the request by the State Department of Health for the $40 million extension and expansion of a collaborative state and city program, raising a series of questions about Maximus, the Virginia-based contractor hired to help enroll the poor in their new insurance plans. The original $24 million contract expired yesterday.

headline.main: State Extends Program to Enroll The Poor in Managed Care Plans

docs.abstract: New York State Comptroller H Carl McCall approves two-year, $40 million extension of program to move one million poor residents on Medicaid into managed care health plans; has reservations about State Department of Health's oversight and monitoring of Virginia-based contractor, Maximus, hired to help enrollment process (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Last winter, 159 funeral directors from around the city crowded into an Italian restaurant on City Island to watch a long-awaited computer demonstration by city and I.B.M. officials: on display was a software program designed to create death certificates online. For the funeral directors, and others, the sense of promise was great. A computerized system in discussion for six years would eliminate the need for funeral directors to track down harried doctors to sign the tens of thousands of forms a year, and then trudge into the city's one and only office for death certificates, in Manhattan, and wait for them to be approved by a clerk.

headline.main: Technical and Other Difficulties Delay Plan for Online Death Certificates

docs.abstract: Computerized system that would create death certificates online and eliminate need for funeral directors to navigate tangled bureaucracy while allowing families to proceed with burials and estate settlement fails in testing, producing false data or crashing entirely; New York City contracted with IBM for $2.5 million to develop project at behest of funeral directors who work within confines of antiquated, costly system; photo (M)
